titleStmt.title: general description of my going around first lightly
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was likely composed after mid-June 1864 and before December 11, 1864. Whitman mentions the Battle of the Wilderness (May 5–7, 1864) and the Battle of Spottsylvania (May 8–21, 1864). He also recalls bringing ice cream to the wounded soldiers in Carver Hospital, which took place in mid-June according to Whitman's "Our Sick and Wounded Soldiers: Visits Among Army Hospitals," published in the New York Times on December 11, 1864. This manuscript may be a list of topics to be included in the Times article.
The following are responsible for particular readings or for changes to this file, as noted: Elizabeth Lorang Ashley Lawson Tim Jackson

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: A Series of Washington Hospital Notes. Written at the bedsides of wounded soldiers. Washington, 1863–1865.

bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

revisionDesc.change: corrections made based on additional review by KP, BB, and EL

body.ab: general description of my going around first lightly to all, & then selecting out the cases that are most proper for special attention or sympathy
bring in description of hospitals toward last
☞ also sum of visits &c, towards very last
towards latter portion four to seight sticksfull about battles of Wilderness, Spottsylvania,—the first wounded, came in in a curious manner, on foot, hobbling, stragglers &c
